I am wondering why the assertEquals is not doing a more thorough 
validation.

Basically instead of :
[code]
      static public void assertEquals ( String message, 
                                        Object expected, 
                                        Object actual) 
      {
        if (expected == null && actual == null)
          return;
        if (expected != null && expected.equals(actual))
          return;
        failNotEquals(message, expected, actual);
      }
[/code]
why not have it like :
[code]
      static public void assertEquals ( String message, 
                                        Object expected, 
                                        Object actual ) 
      {
        if ( expected == null && actual == null)
          return;
        if ( expected != null && actual!= null 
             && expected.equals (actual) && actual.equals (expected))
          return;
        failNotEquals(message, expected, actual);
      }
[/code]

This would make sure that :
  A = B  <=> B = A
which is trivial "math" & sounds to me like a normal default behavior 
(though slower).

Thomas,
